review.title: A Probabilistic-Based Model for Binary CSP
review.abstract: This work introduces a probabilistic-based model for binary CSP that provides a fine grained analysis of its internal structure. Assuming that a domain modification could occur in the CSP, it shows how to express, in a predictive way, the probability that a domain value becomes inconsistent, then it express the expectation of the number of arc-inconsistent values in each domain of the constraint network. Thus, it express the expectation of the number of arc-inconsistent values for the whole constraint network. Next, it provides bounds for each of these three probabilistic indicators. Finally, a polytime algorithm, which propagates the probabilistic information, is presented.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: The core of constraint programming, i.e. its operational character, depends on the mechanism of propagation and research: the propagation part tries to derive new information from the current states of the variables, while the search part, most of the time, consists of an in-depth exploration of the search space. Propagation and search must generally be complicated due to the NP completeness of the CSPs. Therefore, finding a fair balance between efficiency in terms of computation time and effective performance in terms of filtering has always been an important issue in the constraint program community. This paper goes a step further by providing a probable analysis of the constraint network associated with each constraint problem (CSP), leading to a probability-based binary CSP model that allows us to view both the macrostructure (i.e., the interactions between variables by the constraints) and the microstructure as predisposition.

sections.heading: 2 Background material and notations
sections.text: We consider the classical definition of binary constraint networks. A binary constraint network N is a triplet < X, D, C >, where X is a set of n variables, D is the set of their finite domains, and C is the binary constraints, which are believed to be unique without loss of generality. sections.heading: 3 A probabilistic-based model for CSP
sections.text: The solution methods often focus on the state of a variable within the network called microstructure. In addition, the solution methods use criteria based on statistical information based on the past states of variables / constraints. However, such a standpoint loses a lot of information because no information about the future state of the network is taken into account and the global structure of the network is ignored. In this section, we present an original probabilistic model for binary CSP that allows us to define criteria based on the future state of variables that take into account both the macro structure and the microstructure of the constraint network. Assuming that a domain is modified, we want to know which values are more likely than arc inconsistent. First, we introduce a probabilistic model of the network that allows us to properly define the domain modifications as probable events.

sections.heading: 4 Conclusion
sections.text: This paper presented a probabilistic model for classical binary CSPs. This is an original point of view that provides a fine-grained analysis of the constraint network that allows us to better understand both the macrostructure (i.e. interactions between variables by the constraints) and the microstructure (i.e. interactions between compatible values) of a binary CSP.
